newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Autoliv posts Q1 profit on target, market relieved.
newsitem.headline: Autoliv posts Q1 profit on target, market relieved.

text.p: Swedish car safety equipment group Autoliv released a first quarter profit largely in line with expectations on Tuesday and its share rose in relief.
Autoliv posted a five percent rise in pre-tax profit in the first three months of the year to 316 million crowns following higher sales, further integration and continued cost cutting.
The profit was marginally lower than the expected 319 million crowns found by a Reuter poll of analysts.
The report sent Autoliv's share higher and at 1110 GMT it was changing hands at 292 crowns, up three from its Monday close.
"The market was reassured that the report did not contain any nasty surprises," Peter Lawrence, analyst at Kleinwort Benson, told Reuters.

Drugs major Astra shocked the market on Monday by reporting a one percent rise in first quarter earnings which was 500 million crowns lower than expected and made players fear more bad news, analysts said.
In addition, there were some worries about the weak French car market having a negative impact on earnings, analysts said.

"Autoliv has warned somewhat of the downturn on the French car market and market players had possibly worried about a weaker than expected profit," said Gunnar Andersson, analyst at Handelsbanken, explaining the share rise.
Autoliv's sales rose to 3.26 billion crowns from 2.98 billion in the first quarter of 1996 and earnings per share advanced to 3.78 crowns from 3.50 crowns.
Its operating profit rose to 303 million crowns from 284 million, while its operating margin slipped to 9.3 percent from 9.5 percent.
"The report did not contain any surprises and at least key figures, such as sales and operating margin, were as expected," Andersson said.
"Autoliv shows a strong development as the underlying car production was flat or lower on some, for Autoliv important, markets."
Sales of air bags and steering wheels rose nine percent to 1.6 billion crowns and sales of seat belts, including seat components, rose nine percent to 1.7 billion crowns.
"Sales of seat belt pre-tensioners have kept developing well," the company said. "In addition, Autoliv's market share for regular seat belts has increased slightly."
Autoliv is expecting to be able to merge with Morton Automotive Safety Products, the car safety equipment unit of U.S. Morton, in early May, creating Autoliv Inc..
"The merger is very positive and the company will have very good potential," Andersson said.
